snippet: The number of soldiers at Fort Hood has fallen, and as the Army moves away from wartime footing, those who planned to make a career in the military face an uncertain path.
abstract: Number of soldiers assigned to Fort Hood military base has fallen and could continue to shrink as America moves away from wartime footing; decreasing number of soldiers has added to or replaced stress of combat and multiple deployments with anxieties about future careers in military, which may be more uncertain; demand for mental health services at the base has grown over time.

byline.original: By JACK HEALY, SERGE F. KOVALESKI and ALAN BLINDER
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Erica Goode and Sheelagh McNeill from New York; Dave Montgomery from Killeen; and Andy Lehren from Tonsberg, Norway.

lead_paragraph: The number of soldiers at Fort Hood has fallen, and as the Army moves away from wartime footing, those who planned to make a career in the military face an uncertain path.

headline.main: War Pain Yields to New Anxiety Inside Ft. Hood
headline.print_headline: War Pain Yields to New Anxiety at Fort Hood

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
